content.description: The route starts at the far south end of Keyhole, but you can jump on the ridge anywhere you want.  I start near the first really steep section.
content.protection: The pro is scarce in some spots, but with a set of nuts, and Metolius cams 3-9 it is plenty safe.  I like to use extenders rather than regular draws; plan on 5 per pitch.

climbs.name: Mission Impossible
climbs.fa: FA: Harvey Carter, 1960s,  FFA: Bob D'Antonio, Pete Gallagher, 1982, P3 added by P. Gallagher & Larry Schubarth, 1982

content.description:
To find this one, look for the main summit and its starts directly below. The name says it all. This is a fun, trippy route on the west side of Keyhole. This route tends to be a bit loose on the 2 & 3 pitches but makes for some interesting climbing.

P1 .9R, climb to the one and only pin for this pitch, 12 feet up, then up to a good ledge (w/ tree), continue on up a 4th class wall to another good ledge. 110 feet?.

P2 .10b, the fun begins, climb up this wall passing pins being careful not to pull your holds.

P3 .11b. More of the same but harder and a little looser. This is one of the more bold climbs at the Gods, due to the quality of rock, but is fun since it puts you on the summit.

This was originally entered as an area.  The information was moved here to a route.

This is on the back of Keyhole. It is an open area with a large slab on sandstone. Follow small pockets up wall onto the shelf and into the crack above. It feels like 12a, (the crack starts the second pitch). Continue up crack until it ends (10+), and walk off left side. Or, continue up 3rd pitch in a slight overhang (12c). The fourth pitch ends above the Keyhole cave and feels like a 10-.
content.location:
Park at the last parking lot on the Garden Loop, walk down to the Grey Rock rappeling area, then continue toward The Keyhole. The climb is located on the back of Keyhole Rock, between "Old Aid Bolts (10d)" and "

Mission Impossible

(11b)" if you are looking at a guidebook.
